Title.evidence: This trial aimed to assess disease recurrence and survival rates between patients with locally advanced rectal adenocarcinoma (LARC) who underwent total mesorectal excision (TME) after a waiting interval of 8 weeks or less (classic interval; CI) versus more than 8 weeks (long interval; LI) following preoperative CRT.

Trial_Design.evidence: This was a phase III, single-centre, randomized clinical trial.

Participants.evidence: Patients with LARC situated within 12 cm of the anal verge (T3–T4 or N+ disease) were randomized to undergo TME within or after 8 weeks after CRT.

Intervention.evidence: Patients with LARC situated within 12 cm of the anal verge (T3–T4 or N+ disease) were randomized to undergo TME within or after 8 weeks after CRT.

Objective.evidence: This trial aimed to assess disease recurrence and survival rates between patients with locally advanced rectal adenocarcinoma (LARC) who underwent total mesorectal excision (TME) after a waiting interval of 8 weeks or less (classic interval; CI) versus more than 8 weeks (long interval; LI) following preoperative CRT.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The cumulative incidence of locoregional recurrence at 5 years was 10.1 per cent in the CI group and 6.9 per cent in the LI group ( P = 0.143).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients with LARC situated within 12 cm of the anal verge (T3–T4 or N+ disease) were randomized to undergo TME within or after 8 weeks after CRT.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between January 2006 and January 2017, 350 patients were randomized, 175 to each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The cumulative incidence of distant metastasis at 5 years was 30.8 per cent in the CI group and 18.6 per cent in the LI group (sub-HR = 1.78; 95 per cent c.i. 1.14 to 2.78, P = 0.010).
